docs.abstract: Article on obesity problem in United States; process of reducing caloric intake is discussed as effective method for weight control; article holds that way to healthy living is not analyzing what to eat, but rather how much to eat; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In a word -- less. More and more people, young and old, in countries rich and poor, are fat and growing ever fatter. If there are limits to obesity, our species seems not to know about them.
docs.snippet: In a word -- less.    More and more people, young and old, in countries rich and poor, are fat and growing ever fatter. If there are limits to obesity, our species seems not to know about them.

headline.main: Trans Fats to Safe Sex: How Health Advice Has Changed

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column explores how health advice has changed in 25 years Science Times has been published; way in which health is discussed, content of health information and emergence of obesity as major health threat are some differences identified and discussed; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The times (and The Times) sure have changed. On April 18, 1966, Dr. William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson released the findings of an 11-year study of the physiology of sex in their groundbreaking book, ''Human Sexual Response.'' I was in my first year at The Times and my beat included birth control, abortion and venereal disease, among other sex-related subjects. Even so, my editors were reluctant to have a young woman even read the book, let alone have her byline on the article. (It was written instead by a male reporter on cultural affairs.)

headline.main: The Nation: Food Fight; Is Obesity the Responsibility of the Body Politic?

docs.abstract: Expanding girth of Americans draws very different reactions, one from activists who believe government should use legislative power to slim down increasingly obese population, the other arguing that eating habits and weight are matters of personal responsibility; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IN what is shaping up to be the great American food fight, there are two increasingly discordant sides. One insists that government must use its legislative power to slim down an increasingly obese nation. In this view, obesity, like smoking, has become a public health crisis and demands a public health solution. In state legislatures, anti-obesity advocates are pushing bills that would add sin taxes for sodas, require calorie counts on restaurant menus and ban ''foods of minimum nutritional value'' in schools (that means you, Sno-Kone).

docs.abstract: Roger Mummert Out of Order column takes issue with perception that suburbanites are sedentary; holds secret to suburban obesity is free beverage refills at restaurants; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A RECENT study links higher levels of obesity to sprawling suburbs. Acid-tongued commentators who are always eager to poke fun at us suburbanites have seized on the notion that the extra pounds we tote around here where the grass is greener are due to our more sedentary lifestyle. No one has pointed an accusative finger at Long Island in particular, but when I speak with city friends I can sense the snickering.
